Comment: When in doubt -> 1...Nf6
When in doubt -> 1...Nf6

I decided to play for the Nf6/e6/b6 structure which is, more or less, a generally reliable all-purpose formation. If 3. e4 then I figured I could reply with 3...d5 inviting a French structure with 4.e5 Nfd7 5.d4 c5 6.c3 Nc6 7.Nf3 Qb6 8.O-O Be7 or possibly 4.exd5 exd5 with a nicely active open position.

I decided to play for the Nf6/e6/b6 structure which is, more or less, a generally reliable all-purpose formation. If 3. e4 then I figured I could reply with 3...d5 inviting a French structure with 4.e5 Nfd7 5.d4 c5 6.c3 Nc6 7.Nf3 Qb6 8.O-O Be7 or possibly 4.exd5 exd5 with a nicely active open position.
The a3/h3 moves are often criticised as time wasting, but a3 here is actually a very decent move to prevent the common Bb4 pin to the knight.
Grabbing my share of the center, blunting off his bishop, and allowing for the queenside fianchetto to oppose his king's bishop.
These pins can be intimidating, but the bark is often worse than the bite - Nd2 and the pin is neutralised and the bishop ready to be kicked. Perhaps Bf4 was stronger to guard e5.
These pins can be intimidating, but the bark is often worse than the bite - Nd2 and the pin is neutralised and the bishop ready to be kicked. Perhaps Bf4 was stronger to guard e5.
These pins can be intimidating, but the bark is often worse than the bite - Nd2 and the pin is neutralised and the bishop ready to be kicked. Perhaps Bf4 was stronger to guard e5.

Bb4 was taken away, but d6 is a great square as well for the bishop - it, the two knights, and the pawns stake their claim on the center. It will combine nicely to aim at the kingside with the parallel Bb7.

By kicking first, I reserve the right to chase the bishop and castle queenside. 8.Bh4 g5, 8.Bf4 Bxf4, 8.Be3 and the e-pawn is blocked.
By kicking first, I reserve the right to chase the bishop and castle queenside. 8.Bh4 g5, 8.Bf4 Bxf4, 8.Be3 and the e-pawn is blocked.
Likely a positonal mistake - White weakens the king's protection on the King's light squares. The e-pawn often hangs back with the kingside fianchetto

Another mistake I believe - white wastes some time redeploying his bishop. True it was blunted, but 9.O-O Bb7 and playing Ne5 or trying to get a break with c4 would have been more favourable for white.

Time to break with c5 and gain the c-file or possibly cramp with an advance to c4.
Time to break with c5 and gain the c-file or possibly cramp with an advance to c4.

A great outpost for the knight to pressure white (also eyeing the weak c3). If Bxe4 then dxe4 and then 15... e3 to juggle up the kingside.

I believe white made the move to guard c3 from the knight.
Grabbing the semi-open file to bear down on the weak c2/c3 squares.
A mistake - leaving the weak f2 square open!
Threatening mate with Qxf7, and freeing my finachetto'd bishop in an exchange.
Bxe4 was stronger as the knight on d2 was guarding more critical squares.
